items.title: Greenland dispute could suck oxygen from Davos talks, Stubb says

featured_image.name: Finnish President Alexander Stubb speaks at the Annual ...

items.description:
Finnish President Alexander Stubb voiced concerns on Monday that escalating tensions over Greenland will "suck out all the oxygen" at this week's World Economic Forum in Davos, potentially sidelining critical discussions about ending Russia's war in Ukraine and securing the country's reconstruction.[1]

"We are doing everything we can to avoid that," Stubb told reporters in Davos on Monday, adding that "for Ukraine, the best that can come out of Davos is some kind of an agreement on an economic plan or reconstruction".[1]

The warning comes as the 56th World Economic Forum opened January 19 under the theme "A Spirit of Dialogue," with nearly 3,000 participants from more than 130 countries, including approximately 65 heads of state and six G7 leaders. Yet the gathering has been upended by President Donald Trump's threat to impose escalating tariffs on European allies unless they acquiesce to American acquisition of Greenland.[2][3]

items.title: Denmark, Greenland propose NATO Arctic surveillance mission

featured_image.name: TOPSHOT-GREENLAND-DENMARK-US-DEFENCE-NATO

items.description:
Denmark and Greenland have formally proposed establishing a NATO surveillance mission in the Arctic, Danish Defence Minister Troels Lund Poulsen announced Monday after meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte in Brussels. The proposal marks an attempt to address escalating transatlantic tensions sparked by U.S. President Donald Trump's push to acquire the strategically located island.

"We have proposed it, the secretary general has taken note of that, and I think we can now—we hope—define a framework on how that can be concretised," Poulsen told Danish television following the meeting, which also included Greenlandic Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt.[1][2][3]

items.title: Denmark deploys combat troops to Greenland amid Trump threats

featured_image.name: TOPSHOT-GREENLAND-DENMARK-US-DEFENCE-NATO

items.description:
Denmark is deploying a substantial contingent of combat soldiers to Greenland on Monday evening, with Army Chief Major General Peter Boysen accompanying the forces as Copenhagen reinforces its Arctic presence in the face of escalating pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to acquire the self-governing territory.

The Danish Armed Forces confirmed to broadcaster TV 2 that the additional troops are scheduled to arrive in Kangerlussuaq, describing the deployment as "a substantial contribution." Around 100 Danish soldiers had already arrived in Nuuk, Greenland's capital, with a similar number stationed in Kangerlussuaq before the latest reinforcement.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump to meet with global CEOs after Davos keynote address

featured_image.name: Trump to meet global CEOs in Davos, with US policy in spotlight

items.description:
Business executives attending this week's World Economic Forum received an unexpected invitation on Monday: President Donald Trump wants to meet with them after his Wednesday keynote address in Davos, Switzerland.

The U.S. president plans to convene a group of corporate executives following his speech at the forum, according to Reuters and Semafor, though the agenda remains unclear. The invitations, which originated from the White House, sent corporate staffers scrambling to rework schedules that had been months in the making.[1][2]

items.title: German Chancellor Merz seeks Trump meeting at Davos over Greenland

featured_image.name: Merz to Meet Trump in Davos to Avoid Escalation in Trade ...

items.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz announced Monday he will attempt to meet with President Donald Trump at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week to defuse escalating tensions over Greenland, as Europe prepares potential countermeasures against threatened U.S. tariffs.

Speaking at a press conference in Berlin, Merz said European nations that expressed solidarity with Denmark want to prevent the dispute from spiraling further. "We will have the opportunity this week in Davos to discuss this in various meetings. I will try to meet with President Trump on Wednesday," Merz said. Trump is scheduled to deliver a special address at the forum on January 21.[1][2]

items.title: Italian PM Meloni offers to mediate US-Europe standoff over Greenland

featured_image.name: Italy's Meloni Offers to Be Europe's Mediator With Trump on ...

items.description:
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni positioned herself as a potential bridge between Washington and European capitals on Sunday, calling President Donald Trump's tariff threats over Greenland "a mistake" while suggesting the crisis stemmed from a "communication breakdown" rather than fundamental disagreement among allies.

Speaking during a visit to Seoul on January 18, Meloni disclosed that she had spoken directly with Trump "a few hours ago" and conveyed her concerns about the escalating tensions. "There has been a problem of understanding and communication," she told reporters, arguing that European military deployments to Greenland were misinterpreted as anti-American when they were actually intended to deter "other actors" — a reference to Russia and China.[1][2]

items.title: France rejects Trump's Gaza Board of Peace, citing UN concerns

featured_image.name: 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in ...

items.description: France will not accept an invitation to join President Donald Trump's "Board of Peace" initiative aimed at overseeing Gaza's governance, according to a source close to President Emmanuel Macron. The announcement comes as the French government simultaneously pursues its own path of engagement in the region, dispatching nearly 400 tons of humanitarian aid to the war-ravaged territory.[1][2]

items.title: Prince Harry's privacy trial against Daily Mail begins in London

featured_image.name: Prince Harry Appears in Court for Daily Mail Publisher ...

items.description:
Prince Harry arrived at London's High Court on Monday, waving to reporters and saying "good morning" as he entered via a side entrance for the start of what his legal team calls the "final chapter" of his crusade against British tabloid media. The Duke of Sussex, 41, sat in the back row of the courtroom alongside actresses Elizabeth Hurley and Sadie Frost as his barrister, David Sherborne, alleged the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday engaged in "clear, systematic and sustained use of unlawful information gathering" spanning two decades.[1][2]

The civil trial, expected to last nine weeks, sees Harry and six other high-profile claimants accusing Associated Newspapers Limited of illegal practices including phone hacking, hiring private investigators to plant listening devices in homes and cars, and obtaining medical and financial records through deception—a practice known as "blagging". The publisher has "vigorously denied" all allegations, calling them "preposterous smears" and part of a "coordinated effort" against the media.[3][4][5]

items.title: Japan's PM Takaichi calls snap election for February 8

featured_image.name: Japan's Leader Calls for Snap Election in Bid to Expand Power

items.description:
Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi announced Monday that she will dissolve parliament on Friday and hold a snap general election on February 8, just three months after becoming the country's first female leader. The move sets the stage for a high-stakes campaign as Takaichi seeks a stronger mandate to advance her fiscal policies and hardline security stance amid escalating tensions with China.

"I want the public to decide whether Sanae Takaichi is suitable as prime minister," she told reporters at a press conference in Tokyo. Official campaigning will begin on January 27, with only 16 days between the dissolution and voting day, the shortest such period since the end of World War II.[1][2]

items.title: Hotel explosion in Kabul kills at least 7, injures Chinese nationals

featured_image.name: Hotel popular with Chinese visitors attacked in Kabul - Harici

items.description:
A powerful explosion tore through a hotel in central Kabul on Monday, killing at least seven people and injuring 13 others, according to officials and a hospital that treated casualties. The blast struck the heavily guarded Shahr-e-Naw district, considered one of the safest neighborhoods in the Afghan capital.

Italian NGO EMERGENCY, which operates a surgical center in Kabul, confirmed receiving at least 20 patients from the incident, including women and children. The organization reported seven deaths from the explosion that occurred at a hotel on Gulfaroshi Street in the capital's fourth district.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Russia posts record budget deficit as oil revenues collapse

featured_image.name: Russia's seven-month budget deficit exceeds annual target

items.description:
Russia recorded a federal budget deficit of 5.645 trillion rubles ($72.3 billion) in 2025, the largest since at least 1996, according to data released by the Finance Ministry on Sunday. The shortfall more than doubled from 3.47 trillion rubles the previous year, exposing the mounting fiscal strain of nearly three years of war in Ukraine.[1][2]

The record gap came despite aggressive spending cuts in December, when expenditures fell 19% from a year earlier as the government moved to keep the deficit within its revised target of 2.6% of GDP. Finance Minister Anton Siluanov confirmed the target was met in an interview with Interfax last week.[3][4]

items.title: Merz urges restraint as France pushes for EU trade retaliation

featured_image.name: Merz Holds Press Conference At CDU Headquarters

items.description:
Chancellor Friedrich Merz signaled on Sunday that Germany prefers a measured response to President Donald Trump's threat of escalating tariffs over Greenland, putting Berlin on a different track than Paris as Europe's two largest economies grapple with how to handle the unprecedented American demands.

Merz said Germany and its European partners have agreed "that we want to avoid any escalation in this dispute if at all possible," according to his remarks in Berlin on Monday. While French President Emmanuel Macron has formally requested activation of the European Union's most powerful trade weapon—the anti-coercion instrument, often called the EU's "trade bazooka"—Merz indicated Germany would support such measures only "if necessary."[1][2]

items.title: Hackers breach Iran state TV to air exiled prince's protest call

featured_image.name: Iran State TV Hacked for Several Minutes as Opposition Message From Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi Airs Nationwide

items.description:
Hackers breached Iran's state television network on Sunday, hijacking broadcasts for approximately 10 minutes to air anti-regime messages and an address from exiled Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi calling on Iranians to continue their protests against the Islamic Republic.

The cyberattack targeted Iran's Badr satellite, which transmits several state-run provincial channels nationwide, allowing opposition footage to reach millions of homes across the country during prime evening viewing hours. According to Israel's public broadcaster KAN News, the hacked broadcast aired around 9:30 p.m. local time.[1][2]

items.title: Putin invited to join Trump's 'Board of Peace' as 60 nations weigh membership

featured_image.name: Putin issues formal demands to end Ukraine war after meeting with Trump:  report

items.description:
The Kremlin announced Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin has received an invitation to join U.S. President Donald Trump's "Board of Peace," with Moscow saying it is studying the proposal and hopes for further contacts with Washington.[1][2]

The invitation to Putin comes as Trump has dispatched letters to approximately 60 world leaders asking them to become founding members of the new international body, which he will chair for life. Initially conceived to oversee governance and reconstruction in post-war Gaza, the board's draft charter indicates aspirations for a broader mandate addressing global conflicts.[3][4][5][6]

items.title: EU weighs first use of 'trade bazooka' against Trump tariffs

featured_image.name: Europe weighs using trade 'bazooka' against the U.S. as Greenland ...

items.description:
European Union leaders are mobilizing an unprecedented response to President Donald Trump's threat of escalating tariffs on nations opposing his campaign to acquire Greenland, with officials considering activating the bloc's most powerful trade weapon for the first time.

EU ambassadors from all 27 member states convened an emergency meeting in Brussels on Sunday, where the European Commission presented multiple countermeasures, including reactivating a €93 billion retaliatory tariff package and deploying the Anti-Coercion Instrument, a mechanism adopted in 2023 but never triggered.[1][2][3]

items.title: At least 39 killed in Spain's deadliest train crash in over a decade

featured_image.name: Spain's high-speed train crash: what happened? | Reuters

items.description:
At least 39 people were killed and more than 150 injured after two high-speed trains collided Sunday evening in southern Spain, in the country's deadliest rail disaster in more than a decade. Authorities warned on Monday that the death toll could rise as cranes began lifting mangled carriages from the wreckage near the town of Adamuz.

The crash occurred around 7:45 PM local time when the rear carriages of an Iryo train traveling from Málaga to Madrid derailed and crossed onto an adjacent track, slamming into an oncoming Renfe Alvia service headed from Madrid to Huelva. The Renfe train's first two carriages tumbled down a four-meter embankment, sustaining the most severe damage.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: OpenAI says revenue hit $20 billion in 2025, up 233% from prior year

featured_image.name: OpenAI to begin testing ads on ChatGPT in the U.S. - CNBC

items.description:
OpenAI's annualized revenue surpassed $20 billion in 2025, marking a 233% increase from the previous year, the company announced Sunday. The milestone underscores explosive demand for AI services even as the company confronts mounting competitive pressure from Anthropic and Google.

"This is growth on a scale never seen before," Chief Financial Officer Sarah Friar wrote in a blog post detailing the figures. The company's revenue climbed from $2 billion in 2023 to $6 billion in 2024 before reaching the $20 billion mark—roughly a tenfold increase in just two years.[1][2]

items.title: Australian researchers build motor powered by liquid metal

featured_image.name: 2022 | Beyond sci-fi: Researchers manipulate liquid metals ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of New South Wales have developed a motor that operates using a droplet of liquid metal instead of traditional rigid components—a breakthrough that could reshape the future of soft robotics, flexible electronics, and medical devices.

The tiny device, called a liquid metal droplet rotary paddle motor, generates motion through swirling flows inside a liquid metal droplet embedded in a salt solution and exposed to an electric field. A small copper paddle placed within the swirling metal is carried along by these internal flows, creating rotation at speeds of up to 320 revolutions per minute.[1][2][3]

"This is a completely new way to create motion," said Dr Priyank Kumar, a UNSW Senior Lecturer who supervised the project and served as the corresponding author on a paper published in npj Flexible Electronics. "We're harnessing the flow of liquid metal itself to produce rotation, without any traditional moving parts. It's simple, compact, and inherently flexible".[2][1]

items.title: China's birth rate hits record low as population shrinks again

featured_image.name: China birthrate shrinks to lowest on record as policies fail to to lift births

items.description:
China recorded its lowest birth rate since the founding of the People's Republic in 1949, with just 7.92 million babies born in 2025, according to official data released Monday by the National Bureau of Statistics. The figure represents a 17% decline from the 9.54 million births recorded in 2024, dashing hopes that a modest uptick last year signaled a reversal of the country's deepening demographic crisis.[1][2][3]

The birth rate fell to 5.63 births per 1,000 people, marking the lowest level in more than seven decades of record-keeping. Meanwhile, deaths climbed to 11.31 million, the highest mortality rate since 1968, resulting in a net population decline of 3.39 million. China's total population now stands at 1.405 billion, shrinking for the fourth consecutive year.[4][5][6]

items.title: Trump cites Nobel snub to justify Greenland demand in letter

featured_image.name: Trump tells Norway he no longer feels obligation to think only of peace

items.description:
President Donald Trump has told Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre that he "no longer feels an obligation to think purely of peace" after being denied the Nobel Peace Prize, using the perceived slight to justify his demand for American control over Greenland in a letter that has sent shockwaves through transatlantic relations.

The letter, first reported by PBS journalist Nick Schifrin on Sunday and confirmed by multiple outlets including Bloomberg and Reuters, was shared by Trump's National Security Council with several European ambassadors in Washington.[1][2][3]
